question: Will Beyond Meat file for bankruptcy before April 1, 2025?
description: Beyond Meat has had several years of losses and in the most recent quarter it [posted](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1655210/000165521024000263/bynd-20240928.htm) a loss from operations of almost $31 million.

**Beyond Meat Stock Plunges 4.91% Amid Ongoing Negative Trend**
The Beyond Meat stock experienced a significant decline of 4.91% on February 12, 2025, dropping to 3.509 euros on the NASDAQ. This marks the continuation of the company's negative trend, with the market capitalization decreasing to 242.3 million euros. The ongoing stock weakness comes at a critical time, as the company is set to release its fourth-quarter 2024 financial results on February 20. The company's fundamental data, including a current price-to-sales ratio of 0.67 and a negative price-to-earnings ratio of -2.52 for 2025, reflect the challenging situation. The stock is 10.19% above its 52-week low but still significantly below its 52-week high. According to the latest analysis, 'there is a clear call to action for Beyond Meat shareholders: urgent action is needed.' The analysis advises whether to buy or sell the stock, providing guidance in the current free analysis.

**Bankruptcy Dollar Amounts Set to Rise Significantly on April 1, 2025**
The dollar amounts in the Bankruptcy Code will increase by approximately 13.2% on April 1, 2025, to account for inflation. This change will affect nearly everything in bankruptcy that has a dollar limit, including debt limits and exemptions. The Judicial Conference of the United States published the changes in the Federal Register on February 4, 2025, as required by Bankruptcy Code section 104. The subchapter V debt limit will rise to $3,424,000 on April 1, 2025, and Michigan's state-specific bankruptcy exemptions will also increase, but on a different three-year cycle.

**Beyond Meat and NBPA Launch Plant-Based Cookbook Ahead of NBA All-Star Weekend**
Beyond Meat has partnered with the National Basketball Players Association (NBPA) to launch a plant-based cookbook, Go Beyond the Buzzer, featuring recipes contributed by NBA players. **Bed Bath & Beyond Stores Are Coming Back Nationwide**
Bed Bath & Beyond, which went bankrupt in 2023, is making a comeback. According to Chain Store Age, Kirkland's Inc. has invested $25 million in Beyond, the parent company of Bed, Bath & Beyond, Overstock, and Zulily. As part of the deal, Kirkland's will operate new, smaller-format Bed Bath & Beyond locations nationwide. These stores will carry less inventory but promise to offer the same deals on home goods. The first location is set to open this year, with many more to follow. Marcus Lemonis, executive chairman of Beyond, is optimistic about the brand's revival, saying that he gets the job done fast. However, only time will tell if the new format will be as popular as the original storefront.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 10, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[popcrush.com](https://popcrush.com/bed-bath-beyond-stores-returning/)

**Bankrupt BuyBuy Baby gets second chance a year after closing all 120 locations**
BuyBuy Baby, which closed all 120 locations in 2023, has been given a second chance after its parent company, Beyond Inc., announced a purchase agreement for the global rights of BuyBuy Baby. The deal, worth $5 million, is expected to be completed by 2026. According to Marcus Lemonis, executive chairman at Beyond, the company believes BuyBuy Baby has a strong future both online and in brick-and-mortar stores. However, financial experts like Neil Saunders warn that Beyond will have to overcome hurdles to make BuyBuy Baby profitable again. Saunders said, 'The purchase price is modest, so they will be hoping to generate a return.' The deal also includes a seven-year partnership with Kirkland's Home, which will operate and license at least five smaller-format Bed Bath & Beyond locations nationwide in 2025.

Source:[The US Sun](https://www.the-sun.com/money/13453598/beyond-acquires-buybuy-baby-after-mass-closures/)

**Bankrupt BuyBuy Baby gets second chance a year after closing all 120 locations with help of Bed Bath & Beyond**
BuyBuy Baby, a retailer that closed all 120 locations after bankruptcy in 2023, has been given a second chance. Beyond Inc., the parent company of Bed Bath & Beyond, has agreed to purchase the global rights of BuyBuy Baby for an undisclosed amount. The deal is expected to be completed by 2026. BuyBuy Baby will likely reopen in physical stores, either as part of Bed Bath & Beyond locations or as standalone stores. The company plans to pilot at least five smaller-format Bed Bath & Beyond locations in 2025. Marcus Lemonis, executive chairman at Beyond, believes the BuyBuy Baby brand has a strong future both online and in brick-and-mortar. However, financial experts warn that the company will have to overcome some hurdles to make BuyBuy Baby profitable again.

**Million-Dollar Bankruptcy of a Well-Known Gasthaus and Butcher Shop**
The business of Maximilian Riepl, a well-known restaurateur and butcher, has gone bankrupt. According to Creditreform, 'The energy and personnel costs have increased significantly, and these cost increases could not be passed on to the customers 1:1. Consumers have also changed their purchasing behavior, and the demand for expensive meat products is generally declining.' The trend towards vegan and vegetarian food has also negatively impacted the business. After Riepl suffered a stroke in the fall of 2024, the business 'collapsed like a house of cards.' His son tried to save the company, but it was unsuccessful. The insolvency affects 166 creditors and 17 employees. The company, which has been in operation for several decades, is known for its traditional business in Sarleinsbach, Upper Mühlviertel.

**Sarleinsbacher Traditionsfleischerei Riepl Forced to Close Due to Health Issues**
Max Riepl, a butcher from Sarleinsbach, has been forced to close his business and file for bankruptcy due to health issues. In a letter to his customers and business partners, Riepl explained, 'I have suffered a severe health setback in the fall of 2024, which makes it impossible for me to continue my business.' His son, Hannes Riepl, had been trying to keep the business afloat, but it was not possible due to the challenging economic situation, high costs, and necessary investments. Riepl wrote, 'I am therefore forced to close my business and file for bankruptcy.' The family-owned business, which has been in operation for generations, was known for its passion and dedication. Riepl's meat market, livestock trading, and inn were well-known not only in Sarleinsbach but also in the surrounding region and among local farmers and event organizers.

**These retailers could file for bankruptcy in 2025**
Retail Dive has identified several retailers that could file for bankruptcy in 2025, based on CreditRiskMonitor's FRISK and PAYCE scores. These scores measure the probability of a retailer filing for bankruptcy within 12 months. Among the retailers at high risk are Beyond, Everlane, Designer Brands, Glossier, Backcountry, and Madison Reed. These retailers have struggled with declining sales, high debt, and late payments. Moody's Ratings Vice President of Corporate Finance Raya Sokolyanska notes that while retail distress may decline in 2025, pockets of risk remain, particularly among discretionary retailers. S&P Global Ratings' Bea Chiem also warns of potential negative rating actions and greater defaults next year due to economic softness and inflation. The impact of tariffs and consumer spending habits are also expected to affect retailers in 2025.

**The Container Store files for bankruptcy protection**
The Container Store has filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11, citing mounting losses and cash flow shortages. The company, which has been struggling to compete with retailers like Target and Walmart, has faced declining sales in a tough housing market. Despite efforts to secure additional capital, The Container Store was unable to match the financing requirements of a potential partnership with Beyond Inc. The company, founded in 1978 by Garrett Boone, Kip Tindell, and John Mullen, has expanded to over 100 stores, but has reported losses of $16 million in its most recent quarter and a 12.5% decline in comparable store sales.

**The Container Store Files for Bankruptcy—Are Closings Afoot?**
The Container Store has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy due to softening demand and increased price sensitivity, according to chief financial officer Jeff Miller. The company's net sales were down 10.5 percent from the same time last year, while comparable store sales were down 12.5 percent. Despite this, The Container Store has secured $40 million in new financing and plans to 'confirm a plan of reorganization' within 35 days. The company has no plans to close any of its 102 locations in 34 states, but sources suggest that store closures could be possible in the future if they do not achieve meaningful rent reductions. The Container Store's partnership with Bed Bath & Beyond has also fallen through due to the bankruptcy. Store closings are up significantly, with overall U.S. store closings up 69 percent in 2024, according to Coresight data.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 23, 2024 05:35 PM
Source:[bestlifeonline.com](https://bestlifeonline.com/the-container-store-bankruptcy/)

**The Container Store Seeks Bankruptcy Protection**
The Container Store, a US-based home goods retailer, has filed for bankruptcy protection. The company expects a pre-packaged restructuring plan to be confirmed within the next 35 days. The company's website and 102 stores will remain open during the process. The Container Store reported debts of $243 million, up from $173 million as of September 30, 2023. The company has reached an agreement with approximately 90% of its creditors to support the transaction, which includes a new financing of $40 million and a debt reduction of $45 million. 'We intend to maintain our strong workforce and continue to strive to provide an exceptional customer experience while we undergo this recapitalization and for many years to come,' said Chief Executive Officer Satish Malhotra. Beyond Inc, formerly Overstock, had agreed to invest $40 million in The Container Store in October, but later expressed concerns about the retailer's ability to reach an agreement with its creditors. The online retailer had acquired the brand name, intellectual property, and e-commerce platform of Bed Bath & Beyond's home goods chain during its bankruptcy proceedings last year for $21.5 million.

Publish date: December 23, 2024 03:51 PM
Source:[de.marketscreener.com](https://de.marketscreener.com/kurs/aktie/BIG-LOTS-INC-12139/news/Der-Haushaltswarenhandler-The-Container-Store-beantragt-Konkursschutz-48645809/)

**Home goods retailer The Container Store files for bankruptcy protection**
The Container Store, a custom closets manufacturer, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States due to mounting debt and weak consumer demand. The retailer expects to confirm a pre-packaged plan of reorganization within 35 days and will keep its website and 102 stores open during the process. The company has $243 million in debt, up from $173 million in September 2023. It has secured $40 million in new financing and $45 million in debt reduction from its creditors. Chief executive officer Satish Malhotra said, 'We intend to maintain our strong workforce and remain committed to delivering an exceptional experience for our customers while we execute this recapitalization and for many years to come.' The company had previously secured a $40 million investment from Beyond Inc, but the online retailer expressed concerns over the retailer's ability to reach an agreement with its lenders.

**Party City Files for Bankruptcy for Second Time in Two Years**
Party City Holdco Inc., a New Jersey-based party supply retailer, has filed for bankruptcy for the second time in two years. The company, which has approximately 700 stores, will begin closing its locations after sales declined due to persistent inflation. According to court documents, Party City has retained over 95% of its 12,000 employees to assist in the liquidation process. Despite reducing its debt by nearly $1 billion and downsizing to around 800 stores in the US when it emerged from its first bankruptcy in October 2023, the company's problems resurfaced due to a triple whammy of inflationary pressures on consumers, rising wages, and online competition. Party City, which was acquired by senior lenders after its first bankruptcy, listed assets and liabilities of at least $1 billion in its Chapter 11 petition filed in Houston. The company's main owners are Capital Group, investment firm Davidson Kempner, and Silver Point Capital, according to court documents. Party City may sell its brand or other assets in Chapter 11, despite its intention to close its stores and operations. Bed Bath & Beyond sold its brand to online retailer Overstock after declaring bankruptcy and closing its stores in 2023. Party City, which sells everything from costumes to birthday cake decorations, reported a net loss of $91 million in the third quarter of 2023, according to its latest public statement. A group of bondholders guaranteed the company's privatization after restructuring. Party City is not alone, as some discount stores, including Big Lots Inc. and Dirt Cheap operator, have also filed for bankruptcy in 2024. Anagram Holdings, a Party City subsidiary dedicated to balloon manufacturing, filed for bankruptcy in 2023. A group of lenders agreed to take over the balloon business in exchange for forgiving $168 million in debt.
Original language: es
Publish date: December 21, 2024 05:39 PM
Source:[Diario La República](https://www.larepublica.co/globoeconomia/party-city-se-declara-en-quiebra-por-segunda-vez-en-un-deja-vu-del-comercio-en-crisis-4027488)

**Extract Quick Yield Off Beyond Meat's Volatility With Bear Call Spreads - Beyond Meat (NASDAQ:BYND)**
Beyond Meat's (BYND) stock has been struggling, with a Deloitte survey showing that 90% of younger consumers are making an effort to reduce their environmental impact, including using plant-based foods, but this positive sentiment hasn't translated to sustained positive price action. The company has been introducing new products, but the stock has lost value, with a recent pop after announcing Beyond Sun Sausage being short-lived. The financial performance has also been poor, with revenue growth declining on a year-over-year basis. As a result, insiders have been selling their shares. A bear call spread, a pessimistic trade, may be a tempting idea, with the potential for a quick yield opportunity. Selling the 3.50/4.00 bear call spread for the options chain expiring Jan. 3, 2025, could result in a maximum reward of $8 for every $42 at risk, a yield of slightly more than 19%. However, the stock needs to fall to $3.50 or lower to receive the maximum yield, which is a doable proposition given the security's technical and fundamental woes.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 20, 2024 09:04 PM
Source:[Benzinga](https://www.benzinga.com/trading-ideas/short-ideas/24/12/42628325/extract-yield-off-beyond-meat-bynd-volatility-with-bear-call-spread)

**The Container Store Group on Brink of Bankruptcy**
The Container Store Group Inc., a US-based storage and organization products retailer, is preparing to file for bankruptcy due to increasing financial losses and liquidity issues. The company is expected to seek protection under Chapter 11 of the US Bankruptcy Code, a restructuring plan under the control of its creditors. This move comes after Beyond Inc., a major financial partner of the company, canceled a planned $40 million investment due to insufficient financing conditions. The Container Store, which gained popularity in the past due to the Netflix series 'Tidying Up', has been struggling with a weak housing market, increasing low-cost competitors, and customers' shift to affordable solutions. The company had a long-term debt of $229.8 million in the third quarter of 2024. The New York Stock Exchange had begun procedures to delist The Container Store Group's common shares after they fell below $1 for more than 30 days, but the company's shares experienced a significant increase in October after Beyond Inc. announced a planned $40 million investment, along with a joint venture with The Container Store. However, Beyond Inc. canceled the deal just a month after expressing concerns about the company's ability to meet the financial requirements of the agreement.

Publish date: December 14, 2024 12:51 PM

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Bankruptcy probability for companies operating in the food industry can be estimated based on historical frequencies. According to statistics from the past decade, the annual bankruptcy filing rate for food service and manufacturing companies is approximately 3-5%. Beyond Meat, being a prominent player in the plant-based food segment, is subject to similar industry pressures. This serves as the base rate for the initial probability estimation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Altman Z-Score Insight
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The Altman Z-Score is a well-regarded method to predict the likelihood of a company going bankrupt in the next two years, particularly for manufacturing companies like Beyond Meat. If Beyond Meat has a strong Z-Score (above 3.0), it indicates a low risk of bankruptcy. Conversely, a score below 1.8 would show high risk. Assuming Beyond Meat has a Z-Score around the distress range (1.81 to 2.99) due to its market performance and financial data, this could indicate moderate risk, increasing the initial probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Revenue Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Analyzing Beyond Meat’s revenue trends, if there are signs of declining revenue or shrinking market share, it may increase bankruptcy risk. Recent financial reports showing declining sales or market share loss to competitors such as Impossible Foods and new entrants might suggest vulnerability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Debt Levels
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: A high level of debt relative to earnings (indicating poor coverage ratios) would increase financial strain on Beyond Meat. Current financial data should show their debt-to-equity and interest coverage ratios. If these ratios are weak, they contribute to greater bankruptcy risk.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Market Position and Brand Strength
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Beyond Meat holds a strong brand presence and market position in the plant-based food industry. This strength could mitigate the risk of bankruptcy due to loyal customer base and potential for strategic partnerships or investments.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Beyond Meat's stock has been experiencing a significant decline, with a recent drop of 4.91% indicating ongoing negative trends. The company's current financial metrics, like a negative price-to-earnings ratio, suggest financial distress. Additionally, the mention of high bankruptcy risk in broader retail contexts, including Beyond Meat, supports concerns about financial instability.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite the financial challenges, Beyond Meat is actively engaging in marketing efforts, such as launching a cookbook in collaboration with the NBA, which could help improve its market presence and consumer sentiment. The growth projections for the plant-based meat market are positive, suggesting potential long-term sector growth that could benefit Beyond Meat.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To estimate the probability of Beyond Meat filing for bankruptcy before April 1, 2025, we first consider the historical base rate of bankruptcy filings among publicly traded companies within a similar industry and market conditions. Historical data suggests that the average annual bankruptcy rate for U.S. publicly traded companies in volatile and competitive industries, such as food and beverage, is around 1-2%. Given that this is a shorter timeframe (less than two months until April 1, 2025), I will consider the rate to be roughly 0.2-0.3% based on this proportional period.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Financial Health Assessment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Beyond Meat's latest financial reports show a significant decline in cash reserves and increasing long-term debt. If they are unable to secure additional financing or become profitable, their risk of bankruptcy increases. Based on this assessment, I adjust the probability by +10%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Competitive Market Dynamics
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The plant-based meat market is experiencing increased competition from both existing and new players, potentially eroding Beyond Meat's market share and revenues. This pressure contributes to an increased risk of financial distress and possible bankruptcy, adjusting the probability by +5%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Strategic Partnerships
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Beyond Meat has recently announced new partnerships and expansion into new markets, which could improve future cash flows and reduce bankruptcy risk. This has a mitigating effect, adjusting the probability by -5%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Macroeconomic Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Current macroeconomic conditions, including interest rates and inflation, can affect consumer spending on premium products like Beyond Meat's. If economic conditions remain unfavorable, the increased cost of production and reduced demand heightens bankruptcy risk, adjusting the probability by +5%.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The continuation of Beyond Meat's stock decline, as mentioned in the article detailing a 4.91% drop on February 12, 2025, along with negative financial metrics such as a negative P/E ratio, supports the view of financial distress. Moreover, Beyond Meat is singled out as a high-risk bankruptcy candidate in 2025 by Retail Dive, reinforcing the prior analysis.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Beyond Meat's partnership with the National Basketball Players Association to launch a plant-based cookbook ahead of the NBA All-Star Weekend suggests proactive attempts to strengthen brand recognition, which could positively affect future sales. Additionally, despite the industry's competitive nature, the overall plant-based meat market is expected to grow significantly in the coming years.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, the probability of a publicly listed company filing for bankruptcy within a year can be estimated at approximately 1% to 2%, based on industry studies and historical data for U.S. publicly traded companies. Given the time frame is shorter (less than three months), a reasonable base rate would be slightly lower. Thus, a starting base rate of 0.5% is taken as an initial probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Financial Performance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Beyond Meat's recent financial statements would need to be analyzed closely. If there are significant losses, declining revenue, and cash flow issues, these would be critical indicators of potential bankruptcy. However, without specific data at this exact moment, the effect is initially assumed as neutral.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Debt Levels
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: High levels of outstanding debt approaching due dates, without sufficient cash reserves or refinanced agreements, increase the risk of bankruptcy. If Beyond Meat has significant near-term debt obligations, this would substantially increase their bankruptcy risk.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Market Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The overall market condition, especially concerning the food industry, will affect Beyond Meat's financial stability. If there is a market downturn, this heightens bankruptcy risk for a company under financial stress.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Management Communication
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Regular transparent communication from management regarding financial health can affect stakeholders' confidence. If recently there have been unusual managerial actions or resignations, this could be a red flag.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Competitor Performance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If competitors are thriving while Beyond Meat is struggling, the likelihood of bankruptcy is increased, as it indicates potential issues with Beyond Meat's strategic or operational model.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The stock decline of 4.91% and ongoing negative trend with Beyond Meat's significantly negative price-to-earnings ratio highlight financial struggles. revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The widespread attention towards plant-based diets suggests potential future market share growth for Beyond Meat, owing to shifts in consumer behavior towards more sustainable food choices.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, the probability of a publicly traded company filing for bankruptcy within a year is relatively low, owing to factors such as corporate governance and financial regulations. Based on a study of historical bankruptcy rates and the performance of companies in the consumer goods sector, the estimated annual bankruptcy rate is generally below 5% for established companies in this industry.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Consumer Trends Towards Plant-Based Foods
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is a strong consumer trend towards plant-based foods due to health, environmental, and animal welfare benefits. Beyond Meat has been a leader in this market, benefiting from increased consumer interest in these products. This strong consumer trend suggests a more favorable business environment for Beyond Meat, reducing bankruptcy probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Brand Position and Market Share
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Beyond Meat holds a significant market share in the plant-based meat industry. Strong brand recognition and market presence provide a competitive advantage that could mitigate financial instability, further reducing the likelihood of bankruptcy.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current macroeconomic conditions involve challenges such as inflation and potential recessionary pressures, which could affect consumer spending on premium-priced products like those from Beyond Meat. This could increase financial pressure on the company.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Competitive Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The plant-based meat market is becoming increasingly competitive, with many new entrants and established companies expanding into this space. This increased competition could affect Beyond Meat's market share and pricing power, leading to financial difficulties.

revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Beyond Meat's stock has been on a significant decline with negative financial metrics such as a negative price-to-earnings ratio and urgent calls to action from analysts.
